headline.main: An Accord on Regulating Overseas Trading

docs.abstract: Regulators have agreed in principle on a plan to rein in risky trading by banks overseas. | Federal regulators have lifted a ban on advertising by hedge funds, buyout firms and start-up companies seeking capital. | Senators raise questions about the implications of the takeover of Smithfield Foods by a Chinese company. | Larry Page, Google’s chief, is conspicuously absent from a media and tech conference in Sun Valley, Idaho.

Friday’s selections include how much the government pays companies for wiretaps and access to e-mails, and a Google page that assembles autocomplete suggestions into a kind of poetry.

docs.snippet: Mistreatment of children did not drop during the recession after all, as had previously been thought....
docs.lead_paragraph: Mistreatment of children did not drop during the recession after all, as had previously been thought.

headline.main: How Googling Unmasks Child Abuse

docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by economist Seth Stephens-Davidowitz describes his methodology in study finding that child abuse greatly increased as a result of the recession; used an analysis of anonymous aggregate Google searches and contends his findings, contrary to pronouncements of many child-welfare experts, show that one should be skeptical of statistics based on official reports of crime in general.

docs.snippet: The American novel reconsidered, with help from a Google database....
docs.lead_paragraph: The American novel reconsidered, with help from a Google database.

headline.main: Crunching Literary Numbers

docs.abstract: Gray Matter column by history Prof Marc Egnal describes his research using Google's Ngram database to determine whether technologies of Big Data can transform society's understanding of American novels; study will be published in journal Social Science History.

headline.main: Sold Back to Its Founder, Frommer’s to Publish Anew
headline.print_headline: Sold Back to Its Founder, Frommer’s to Publish Anew

docs.abstract: Arthur Frommer, having bought his namesake brand of travel guides back from Google in April, is moving quickly to release fresh batch under new name of FrommerMedia; has struck deal with Publishers Group West, member of the Perseus Books Group, to distribute and help market and promote the books

docs.snippet: Even before Edward J. Snowden arrived in a Moscow airport, Russia had been pressing for greater access to social networking and e-mail data....
docs.lead_paragraph: Even before Edward J. Snowden arrived in a Moscow airport, Russia had been pressing for greater access to social networking and e-mail data.

headline.main: N.S.A. Leaks Revive Push in Russia to Control Net
headline.print_headline: N.S.A. Leaks Revive Push In Russia to Control Net

docs.abstract: Members of Russia's Parliament cite Edward J Snowden's leaks of classified information as part of renewed push for tighter government control of Internet; group hopes to compel global Internet companies like Google and Microsoft to comply with rules on personal data storage; experts say rules, in addition to protecting personal data, would provide back door for Russian law enforcement into services like Gmail.

docs.snippet: The company has begun talks with major media companies about licensing TV channels, according to people with knowledge of the meetings....
docs.lead_paragraph: The company has begun talks with major media companies about licensing TV channels, according to people with knowledge of the meetings.

headline.main: Google Said to Weigh Supplying TV Channels
headline.print_headline: Google Said To Weigh Supplying TV Channels

docs.abstract: Google has begun talks with major media companies about licensing TV channels; no deals are imminent, but meetings are sign of newfound race to sell cablelike services via the Internet, creating alternative to current television packages that 100 million American households buy.

docs.snippet: Apple’s steps to reimagine television, like teaming up with ESPN, stand in stark contrast to efforts by Google to compete with established companies....
docs.lead_paragraph: Apple’s steps to reimagine television, like teaming up with ESPN, stand in stark contrast to efforts by Google to compete with established companies.

headline.seo: Apple’s Move Into TV Relies on Cooperation With Industry Leaders
headline.main: Pushing the Right Buttons

docs.abstract: Apple is taking partnership route as it tries to reimagine television, collaborating with distributors like Time Warner Cable and programmers like Walt Disney Co on apps; its steps stand in stark contrast to efforts by Google to compete with established companies.

docs.snippet: The European Commission said that Google’s proposal for addressing antitrust concerns did not go far enough and that the company would need to come up with a better plan....
docs.lead_paragraph: The European Commission said that Google’s proposal for addressing antitrust concerns did not go far enough and that the company would need to come up with a better plan.

headline.main: In European Antitrust Fight, Google Needs to Appease Competitors
headline.print_headline: In European Antitrust Fight, Google Needs to Appease Competitors

docs.abstract: European Commission says Google’s proposal for addressing antitrust concerns does not go far enough, and demands that it come up with more far-reaching remedies or potentially face fine of up to $5 billion; it is significant setback for company.

byline.contributor: James Kanter reported from Brussels, and Claire Cain Miller from San Francisco.
byline.original: By JAMES KANTER and CLAIRE CAIN MILLER

docs.snippet: The second-quarter income announcement showed the desktop search business continued to slow, while ad prices fell....
docs.lead_paragraph: The second-quarter income announcement showed the desktop search business continued to slow, while ad prices fell.

headline.main: Google Results Show Struggle With Mobile
headline.print_headline: Google Results Show Struggle With Mobile

docs.abstract: Google reports second-quarter income showing that its desktop search business continued to slow, while ad prices fell; profit was $3.23 billion, or $9.54 a share, up from $2.79 billion, or $8.42 a share in year-ago quarter; revenue rose 19 percent to $14.11 billion from $11.8 billion.

docs.snippet: The merger of Omnicom and Publicis signals that advertising is now firmly in the business of collecting and selling the personal information of millions of consumers....
docs.lead_paragraph: The merger of Omnicom and Publicis signals that advertising is now firmly in the business of collecting and selling the personal information of millions of consumers.

headline.main: Two Ad Giants Chasing Google in Merger Deal
headline.print_headline: Two Ad Giants Chasing Google In Merger Deal

docs.abstract: Omnicom and Publicis announce merger that will create largest advertising company in world, seeking to compete with Google for larger share of online marketplace; deal signals that advertising is now firmly in the business of Big Data, collecting and selling personal information of millions of customers.

byline.contributor: Vindu Goel and Quentin Hardy contributed reporting.

docs.snippet: A range of start-ups and big companies like Google are working on what is known as predictive search — new tools that act as robotic personal assistants, anticipating what you need before you ask for it....

headline.main: Daily Report: Apps That Anticipate Your Needs

docs.abstract: A range of start-ups and big companies like Google are working on what is known as predictive search — new tools that act as robotic personal assistants, anticipating what you need before you ask for it.

docs.snippet: Technology companies are rushing into predictive search, developing apps like Google Now that process digital clues to anticipate what users want to know....
docs.lead_paragraph: Technology companies are rushing into predictive search, developing apps like Google Now that process digital clues to anticipate what users want to know.

headline.main: Apps That Know What You Want, Before You Do
headline.print_headline: New Apps Know the Answer Before You Ask the Question

docs.abstract: Technology companies are rushing into predictive search, developing apps like Google Now that process digital clues to anticipate what users want to know; technology is the latest development in Web search, and one of the first that is tailored to mobile devices; it does not even require people to enter a search query, as one's context--location, time of day and digital activity--is the query.

docs.snippet: But the shares of the social network giant still have a way to go. In comparison, the Nasdaq market is up more than 20 percent, and Google more than 40 percent since the May 17, 2012, market debut of Facebook.,...
